newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovakia issues GSM licences, Eurotel conditional.
newsitem.headline: Slovakia issues GSM licences, Eurotel conditional.

text.p: The Slovak Ministry of Transport, Post and Telecommunications said on Wednesday that it had officially issued two GSM mobile telephone licences to Slovak-U.S. joint venture Eurotel sro and Slovtel a.s..

"On Wednesday evening the ministry officially signed granting of the two GSM licences with representatives of Slovtel and Eurotel," Stanislav Vanek, head of the ministry's telecommunications department, told Reuters.
But the licence for Eurotel, which is 49 percent owned jointly by US West Media Group and Bell Atlantic Corp, is conditional.
The Eurotel partners still have to create a new company to operate the second GSM (general system for mobile) network complying with a government demand that it be at least 60 percent Slovak-owned.

"The ministry has formally granted the second licence to Eurotel under the contract for the NMT system signed in 1991, and its owners have 90 days to create a joint-stock company according to tender conditions," Vanek said.
Eurotel, which is 51 percent owned by state-run telecom company Slovenske Telekomunikacie (ST), already operates the analogue NMT system, currently Slovakia's only mobile network.
The present composition of Eurotel does not meet a tender condition of a maximum 40 percent foreign ownership.
Vanek said the ministry expected Eurotel's owners to meet the deadline for creating the new company, but warned that they could lose their licence if they failed to do so.
Talks on the ownership structure have dragged on for months. In July ST said it had agreed in principle with its two U.S. partners to create the new company.
ST said negotiations concentrated mainly on executive rights in the new company and the split of investments. ST ruled out any changes to the make-up of the group.

Slovtel, a consortium of four Slovak energy companies, the state monopoly gas distributor and a private firm Hanco sro, which teamed up with France Telecom, earlier this summer won the ministry's public tender for the other licence.
